column1: Heidelberg was the centre of the epoch of Romantik (Romanticism) in Germany. The phase after Jena Romanticism is often called Heidelberg Romanticism (see also Berlin Romanticism). There was a famous circle of poets (the Heidelberg Romantics)
column2: such as Joseph von Eichendorff
column3: Johann Joseph von Görres
column4: Ludwig Achim von Arnim
column5: and Clemens Brentano. A relic of Romanticism is the Philosophers' Walk (German: Philosophenweg)

column7: overlooking Heidelberg.

column1: The Romantik epoch of German philosophy and literature
column2: was described as a movement against classical and realistic theories of literature
column3: a contrast to the rationality of the Age of Enlightenment. It elevated medievalism and elements of art and narrative perceived to be from the medieval period. It also emphasized folk art
column4: nature and an epistemology based on nature
column5: which included human activity conditioned by nature in the form of language
column6: custom and usage.
